intro: Pectiantia pentandra, commonly known as the five-angled pectin, is a flowering plant native to tropical regions of Africa. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes cotton and hibiscus. The plant is characterized by its pentagonal-shaped leaves and showy, pinkish-white flowers that bloom in clusters. Its fruit is a capsule that splits open to release small, hairy seeds. Pectiantia pentandra is often cultivated for its ornamental value and has traditional uses in some local cultures.
